facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 92 of 1954 filed in Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated January 28, 1953 of Calcutta High Court in Award Case No. 105 of 1952.

facts.text: On April 6, 1951, appellant company entered into contract with respondent company for supply of 5,000 maunds of Nikhli and/or Ashuganj Jute at certain prices according to quality, shipment during July and/or August 1951.

facts.text: On September 26, 1951, appellant company through solicitors wrote to respondent company intimating cancellation of contract and demanding Rs. 1,95,000 as damages based on difference between contract price and market price on September 17, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: November 2, 1951, referred the dispute to the arbitration of the Bengal Chamber of Commerce in terms of the arbitration clause companytained in that companytract.

facts.text: Raw Jute Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, W. Ben. Act VI of 1951 came into force on March 21, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was in force at all times material to these proceedings though the same was subsequently repealed on August 5, 1952.

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated January 23, 1953 allowed respondent's application, declared award null and void, parties to bear own costs.

facts.text: Appeal filed against High Court judgment upon certificate of fitness granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, as already stated, has been filed against the judgment of the High Court upon a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: No other point has been urged before us and for reasons stated above this appeal must be dismissed.

To regulate the prices of jute and to empower the Government to fix its maximum prices, the West Bengal Legislature passed an Act called the West Bengal Jute  Control of Prices  Act, 1950,  W. Ben. VI of 1950  which came into force on March 15,1950.

concepts.unlisted_label: West Bengal Jute Control of Prices Act, 1950 (W. Ben. VI of 1950)
concepts.unlisted_description: Act to regulate jute prices and fix maximum prices

anchor.surface_text: On December 14,1950, the Government of West Bengal promulgated an Ordinance called the Raw Jute  Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions  Ordinance, 1950  XVII of 1950  for the better regulation of the jute trade.

concepts.unlisted_label: Raw Jute Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions Ordinance, 1950 (XVII of 1950)
concepts.unlisted_description: Ordinance for regulation of jute trade and constitution of Central Jute Board

anchor.surface_text: the award was a nullity in that the contract containing the arbitration clause was void under the provisions of the Raw Jute  Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions  Act, 1951, Ben. VI of 1951  which was then in force.

concepts.unlisted_label: Raw Jute Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1951 (W. Ben. VI of 1951)
concepts.unlisted_description: Act replacing Ordinance, regulating raw jute sales to jute mills

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 was expressed in the following terms -  5.  1  No person shall sell or agree to sell raw jute to the owner of a jute-mill and not owner of a jute mill shall buy or agree to buy raw jute save and except in pursuance of a contract for the sale or the supply of raw jute entered into in the manner provided in section 6.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits sale or agreement to sell raw jute to jute mill owners except per s.6; such contracts void per s.5(2); contravention punishable.
concepts.unlisted_description: Regulates contracts for sale/supply of raw jute to jute mills; voids non-compliant contracts

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 laid down the manner in which all contracts for the sale or supply of raw jute with the owners of jute mills were to be entered into.

concepts.interpretation: Specifies manner for entering contracts for raw jute sales to mills via Board procedures.
concepts.unlisted_description: Prescribes procedure for valid raw jute contracts with jute mills

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 ran as follows-  7.  1  No person shall deliver or cause to be delivered to the owner of a jute-mill and not owner of a jute-mill shall accept or cause to be accepted any raw jute save and except in pursuance of a contract for the sale or the supply of raw jute entered into in the manner provided in section 6.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits delivery/acceptance of raw jute except per s.6 contracts; effective from appointed day.
concepts.unlisted_description: Regulates delivery of raw jute to mills

anchor.surface_text: The expression appointed day occurring in s. 7  3  quoted above was thus defined in s. 2  1  of that Ordinance 2  1  I appointed day means the date specified by the State Government by notification in the Official Gazette as the appointed day for the purpose of this Ordinance

The first fifteen sections of the Act were almost verbatim reproductions of the fifteen sections of the Ordinance and only one new section was added as the sixteenth section reading as follows- The Central Jute Board constituted, any rule made, any notification or licence issued, any direction given, any contract entered into,

concepts.interpretation: Creates twin fictions: Act deemed commenced Dec 14 1950; actions under Ordinance deemed under Act. Compels mutatis mutandis reading of notification to apply to Act's ss.5,6,7.

anchor.surface_text: A cursory perusal of s. 16 will, however, show that there are two fictions created by that section One is that the Act shall be deemed to have commenced on December 14, 1950, and the other is that the notification issued under the Ordinance shall be deemed to have been issued under the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Fictions must be given full effect, extending beyond mere issuance to substantive application via substitution.

concepts.interpretation: Necessary to substitute 'Act' for 'Ordinance' in notification to effectuate s.16 fictions.

arguments.claim: S.16 creates two fictions: Act deemed commenced Dec 14 1950; notification deemed issued under Act

anchor.surface_text: A cursory perusal of s. 16 will, however, show that there are two fictions created by that section One is that the Act shall be deemed to have commenced on December 14, 1950, and the other is that the notification issued under the Ordinance shall be deemed to have been issued under the Act.

arguments.claim: Petitioner's cited precedents inapplicable as no statutory deeming fiction like s.16 in those cases

anchor.surface_text: The decisions relied on by the learned Attorney General can have no application to the present case. In those cases there was no statutory provision for deeming the provision of the charter party referring all disputes under the charter party to arbitration as an integral part of the provisions of the bill of lading

holdings.text: Section 16 of the Raw Jute Act creates two statutory fictions: the Act is deemed to have commenced on December 14, 1950, and the notification issued under the Ordinance is deemed to have been issued under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: A cursory perusal of s. 16 will, however, show that there are two fictions created by that section One is that the Act shall be deemed to have commenced on December 14, 1950, and the other is that the notification issued under the Ordinance shall be deemed to have been issued under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.16 identifies two distinct deeming provisions (fictions).

holdings.text: The statutory fictions created by s.16 compel the court to read the notification mutatis mutandis by substituting 'Act' for 'Ordinance' to give full effect to the legislative intent.

anchor.surface_text: In other words the creation of the statutory fictions compels us to adopt the principle of mutatis mutandis and to substitute the word Act for the word Ordinance used in the notification, so as to give full effect to the fictions created by the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Treating Act as commencing Dec 14 1950 erases Ordinance; full effect to fictions requires adjusting notification language via mutatis mutandis.

holdings.text: The ambit of the fictions in s.16 extends beyond mere deeming of issuance to reading the notification as issued under the Act with necessary substitutions.

anchor.surface_text: We see no reason in support of the contentions of the Attorney General that the fiction raised by s. 16 stops short at mere issuing of the notification. The ambit of the fiction appears to us to cover not only the issuance of the notification but to extend to our reading it as having been one issued under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fiction cannot stop at issuance; must enable substantive operation under Act by altering referential terms.

holdings.text: Sections 5, 6 and 7 of the Act were brought into force effective December 30, 1950, rendering non-compliant contracts void under s.5(2).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this line of argument. ... so as to give full effect to the fictions created by the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification deemed under Act via s.16 fictions brings ss.5,6,7 into force; contract non-compliant and thus void.

holdings.text: Precedents in Hamilton & Co. v. Mackie and T.W. Thomas & Co. v. Portsea Steamship Co. are inapplicable as they lacked equivalent statutory deeming fictions.

anchor.surface_text: The decisions relied on by the learned Attorney General can have no application to the present case. In those cases there was no statutory provision for deeming the provision of the charter party referring all disputes under the charter party to arbitration as an integral part of the provisions of the bill of lading

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing facts: no s.16-like deeming provision in those cases requiring adjusted reading.

holdings.text: The appeal is dismissed, upholding the High Court's declaration that the award is null and void.

anchor.surface_text: No other point has been urged before us and for reasons stated above this appeal must be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 5,6,7 in force; contract void ab initio; arbitration clause invalid; award unenforceable.

He submits that it is number for the companyrt to alter the terms of the numberification so as to make it possible to read it as a numberification made under the Act.

precedents.case_name: Hamilton and Co. v. Mackie and Sons
precedents.cited_proposition: Deeming a provision from a charter party as part of a bill of lading renders it insensible and meaningless, as the court cannot alter its terms
precedents.cited_holding: an arbitration clause referring all disputes arising out of the charter party was wholly out of place and meaningless as a term of the bill of lading

anchor.surface_text: A cursory perusal of s. 16 will, however, show that there are two fictions created by that section One is that the Act shall be deemed to have commenced on December 14, 1950, and the other is that the notification issued under the Ordinance shall be deemed to have been issued under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We see no reason in support of the contentions of the Attorney General that the fiction raised by s. 16 stops short at mere issuing of the notification. The ambit of the fiction appears to us to cover not only the issuance of the notification but to extend to our reading it as having been one issued under the Act.
